author: Khaleej Times
title: UAB first-half profit up 5%
text:
(MENAFN - Khaleej Times) United Arab Bank, or UAB, on Tuesday said its 2015 first-half net profit rose five per cent to Dh344 million due to the bank's customer-centric approach and positive economic indicators of the country.

The Sharjah-based lender said its total income up by three per cent to reach Dh696 million aided by continued strong performance in net interest income, which climbed seven per cent compared to similar first half period in 2014).

The bank also maintained its net interest margins through its diversified lending portfolios and optimally managing its cost of funds. Operating expenses during January-June 2015 period advanced eight per cent to Dh217 million.

Shaikh Faisal bin Sultan bin Salem Al Qassimi, Chairman of the UAB board of directors, said this year marks a truly historic milestone for UAB as the bank celebrates its 40th anniversary following its inception in 1975.

"Throughout the past four decades, the Bank has successfully prospered in line with the country's economic growth and adapted to the market's changing needs, whilst remaining true to its customer-centric traditions."

The bank's provisions for credit losses in 2015 first half amounted at Dh134 million. With these provisions UAB has a coverage ratio as at June 30, 2015 of 112 per cent on its non-performing loans, which represents 2.9 per cent of gross loans.

Total loans and advances improved by three per cent to Dh18.3 billion while customer deposits stood firm at Dh18.2 billion emphasizing the ongoing sustainability of the bank's operating model. The Bank is rated by Moody's as Baa1 with a stable outlook.

Paul Trowbridge, chief executive officer of UAB, said 2015 first-half results provides further testament to the sustainability of the bank's long-term strategy.

"During the period, we generated solid, underlying profitable growth and we are confident this gives us a platform to meet a more challenging economic outlook as we move into the second half of 2015," Trowbridge concluded.
